Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding the Interactions Between Precipitation and Pastureland Management Strategies in Contributing to Locust Outbreaks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Locust swarms affect the livelihoods of many people worldwide, across more than 60 different countries. Recent research suggests locust swarms can be triggered in response to low nitrogen in their host plants. Intensive grazing is known to trigger these low-nitrogen conditions. Similarly, past evidence supports that increased precipitation may increase the rate at which soil nitrogen stocks are depleted, leading to favorable conditions for locust outbreaks. These interactions are particularly important to understand given increased worldwide demand for animal products and expectations for increased rainfall in the region, which unmanaged could increase the frequency and intensity of locust outbreaks. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Le Kang at the Inner Mongolia Grassland Ecosystem Research Station (IMGERS) in Inner Mongolia, China. IMGERS has several parcels under long-term management utilizing different grazing systems, and is an area of intensive research on the Mongolian locust, Oedaleus asiaticus.

This study will utilize a paired plot design, sampling from 1m circular plots on continuously grazed parcels at 1.5 and 9 sheep/ha stocking rates. Each plot will receive either an ambient (1x) or supplemented (2x) precipitation treatment. Soil NO3- and NH4+ will serve as response variables, collected using partially enclosed ion-exchange resin membranes over two week intervals on each plot. Grass nitrogen and carbon content will be measured to assess plant nutrient uptake across treatments, and confined, field-captured locust nymphs will be used to assess the optimality of host plants as a food source in response to treatment type. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grazing is a major land use in the world’s dry areas. Overgrazing, wherein more animals are confined to a parcel of land than the parcel can easily recover, is a major problem on grasslands, and may ultimately lead to desertification in these areas.

Future climate will be increasingly defined by extreme events, yet the effect of extreme events on grazed landscapes is not well understood. This may have important grassland management implications, because different levels of grazed landscapes may exhibit different responses to extreme events, and display different potential to quickly recover from these disturbances.

Nitrogen is a limiting nutrient in many grassland systems, and nitrogen availability is mediated by moisture availability. In dry grasslands, where moisture is usually limited, plants are most able to uptake nitrogen in the period immediately following soil wetting. Overgrazed landscapes, due to different soil characteristics and lower density of plants, may be less able to take advantage of these short-term periods of nitrogen availability. Because nitrogen is a highly soluble nutrient, if not quickly retrieved by a plant, it may be leached through the soil profile and lost from the ecosystem—contributing to long-term degradation.

Additionally, in the Inner Mongolia pastureland, the project has an additional dimension: locust outbreaks. Locust outbreaks are a major problem worldwide, affecting over 60 countries, and contributing to famine and food insecurity. Recent research has discovered that locust outbreaks may be triggered by low nitrogen content in plant tissue. Due to the potential for precipitation and grazing to interact in affecting N availability, the results of this study may have implications for better understanding and managing the factors that contribute to locust outbreaks.

Early results from the study reveal a significant interaction between precipitation, grazing, and nitrogen availability. As predicted, nitrogen was least available in dry soils. While nitrogen was more highly available in soils that received the water addition, nitrogen availability was greatest in ungrazed and ungrazed plots, and least available in the overgrazed plots. Nitrogen availability was lowest in the areas with highest grazing pressure. Future testing of plant tissue will reveal the extent to which these changes in soil nitrogen translated to plant nitrogen, and subsequently reveal the role precipitation in contributing to locust outbreaks.
